editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: WRITTEN By the LORD Viscount FAVVLKLAND.

p.hi: Scientia non habet Inimicum, Praeter Ignorantiam.

div.p: LONDON. Printed by W. G. for R. Crofts at the Crown in Chancery-Lane under Sergeants-Inne. 1664.

list.item:
De Loome.
La Gitterne. Attendants to the Duke.
De Bereo, A Duke, Brother to the King.

Torguina.
De Prate. Ladies to the Dutchesse.

div.head: THE Mariage Night.
Actus primus, Scena prima.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: POssible?— Dessandro quit from his Command oth' Cittadel? so sharply too? Brushing times, my Lord: Pray, by virtue of what offence?

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: It may be treason to ask their wisdoms that; But the huge Mountebank, the vulgar Rout quarrell'd with's Religion, 'cause 'tis not in the smallest Print: And the King was to say nothing.

sp.speaker: Pirez
sp.p: Good King: I could wish something, and heartily if I durst: Well, from grave hypocrisie and beardlesse wisdome, good heaven deliver us: Nothing in his great Fathers Memory, to hold him worthy of his place?

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: That makes him taste it to the extremity of Sense and Anger.

sp.speaker: Pirez▪
sp.p:
Let us but slight some Gull, or his gay dresse (whose Clothes▪ and Folly, are his sense of honour) how it will conjure up his blood, and bend his Brow? And can Dessandro want a just and valiant anger
to feel the merits of so brave a Father, and his own (kept at a noble height) rendred disgrac'd and fullied? he may believe a' has deserved better, both in his father and himself: But how does his Resolution take it?

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: As Fire and Air comprest, when strugling they break forth in Thunders; or the vex'd wind amongst a Grove of Trees, spending his Scorn and Rage.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: Men of his Soul and Constitution cannot play with their Passions; and stroke' um tame, so provoked.
The Duke.

sp.speaker: Duke.
De Castro.
sp.p: We are the Creatures of your Favour, and but own our lives to acknowledge it.—

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: Here's State embroidery:— but pray'e, what holyday things be they that spread so in his Train? I don't remember I left such faces in the Court.

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: The first of them stalkes in a knighthood, like A Boy in a Dutch Burgers doublet; and 'tis as much too wide for him; a' his travel'd, and speakes Languages, as a Barbers Boy plays oth' Gitterne; And those gay Clouts Sir came out on's Fathers Shop.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: His Remnants: the Other: that looks like the Age to come, which must be worse then this.

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: His Fortune and Industry has prefer'd him to be Barber and Pimp; Two mens places, till of late our Noblemen, growing frugal, do find one may do both the Imployments.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: It is both thriving and gentile.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Gentile indeed; for they have produced Knights, and made Statesmen of broken Citizens (with the help of a Wife) But he whose youth and sorrow shews him like a fair day, set in a Cloudy Evening is—

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: The Lord De Castro; I know him, and me thinks some sparks of his Father, great Valesco's Character, shines in this young man, through all the darknesse of his Fate.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: That Name alone, has glory enough to make him a brave presage to us: Duke's Fathers Character was deriv'd and circled in himself; And a full age of Men shall rarely shew another of so much great and ballanc'd Man in't.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: They are all Court Fancies: Pageants of State, and want allowance both of Brain and Soul to make their Blood and Titles weight.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: He was strangely shuffled to the Block.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: That Blow did bleed Castile too weak, and left us in a faint and sickly pang.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: The Pulse, Sir, of Castile beats in another temper then when you left it.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: I find it: The City wears a Cap, and looks as if all were not right there.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Except their Wives.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: The Court me thinks has strangely chang'd Complexion too.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.l: The Clergy has catch'd the Falling Sicknesse;
The Court, a deep Consumption; and that

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: I know not what disease the Court has; but the Lords look as if they had over sate themselves at Play, and lost odds; so scurvily.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: How does your Lordship find the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p:
I ha' not been amongst um yet, to take up my Arrears; only had the Court happinesse to
kisse her hand, who in her self, contracts them all for Grace and Lustre, the Widow Dutchesse Claudilla.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Why there my admiration leaves you; I Grant her a brave and Courtly Girle: has trim and dazle enough of white and red, to attract the eye, like an indifferent Copie, Flourish'd with Golden trailes; but place your Judgement nearer, it retreats and Cryes you mercy for the mistake: At distances, she is a Goodly Landskip.

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.p: Alas, her blooming beauties yet languish and Pine or'e her Husbands Herse, like Roses scatter'd from the Mornings brow, into the dayes Parch'd Lap.

sp.speaker: Samp.
Pir.
sp.p: A brave young man, and one that is more Honour to his Title than it to him; But when must their Hymenial Tapers flame? and she offer her Turtle Pantings at the Altar, Purpling the Morn with Blushes as she goes and scatter such Bright Rayes, as the Sun may dresse his Beams with for that dayes Glory.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: After he has Celebrated his Sister to Dessandros hand, he will not defer those Minutes Long, and he thinks himself behind in some expression of their Frienpship, until the knot meet there.

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.p: Cleara is a Lady of a sweet and honoured Fame.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: All other of her Sex are dull and sullied imitations, Pale Glimmerings, set by her: What er'e the modest fictions of sweetned Pens has meant, she is their Moral.

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.p: You speak like one that knows what Virtue is, and can love it.

div.stage: Enter De Castro, and Dessandro to them.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: I thank the Duke, he has a Right Soul; But, Prethee no more of these sad Consolations, they hang upon my heart like pondrous w • ights at trembling wyres: Or like the dull Labourings of that Clock which groan'd our dear Father's Fatal minute.

sp.speaker: De Cast.
sp.p: I have done.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: I could chide this tame and phlegmy vapour from my blood: Our Passions melt into soft Murmurs, like hollow Springes:— the Manhood of cold hinds wou'd not be tempted to this sense, but leap with rage in their eyes; Brother, it wou'd; and wake 'um into Tempests; A wretched Flie, would shew its spleen.

sp.speaker: De Cast.
sp.p: This Anger will but shew men where you bleed and keep the wound still Green.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: The Scar will stick for ever:— Oh; the dark Hypocrisie and Jugling of our Times? Great Men are Slaves to Slaves, and we are theirs: The Law's a Tame Wolfe, Cowards and Fools may stroak with Giving hands, while he shall Couchant lie, and wagg the Taile; but shew his Fangs at you and I: A Noble wish is dangerous; is't not my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.p: What Dessandro?

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: The Vulgar's a Kennel of black mouth'd dogs that worry mens deserts and Fame: my Curse fester in their Temples.

sp.speaker: De Cast.
sp.p: Prethee Dessandro, collect these Scatter'd thoughts.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: I'le hollow them through all the world, and say't again; Worth and Honour now are Crimes, and Giants 'gainst the State: My Lords; shall's be merry and talk something the Hangman may thank us for?

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.p: Treason? I vow Dessandro, I speak the worst ex tempore, of any man living.

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: I could mutter it well enough; but I'm to marry A City Widow, and buy a Place at Court.

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.p: When I have sold my Land we'l venture on A Merry Catch, and ever subscribe your Servant Noble Dessandro.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: I shall find a Time and Place to pay your Lordship the Accompt of my engagements.

sp.speaker: De Cast.
sp.p: Brother, my Attendance calls me to the King; I'le wait upon your Lordship, if y' are for the Court.

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.p: Your Lordships Servant thither.—

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: So streams divide and Ruffle by their banks; My Brother's of a safe contracted bosome; Can strangle his labouring Rages in their thought; When they do tug like poysons at my brest, until I give them Air: But I'le observe and Creep into Mens Souls: Hugg my dear Anger to my self, until it gnaw my Intrails through, that men may Court my patience, and discourse, As now they shun it. And when black night has stretcht her Gloomy limbs, and laid her head upon some Mountain Top (bound up in foggy Mists) then keep my haunts by some dull groaning stream with screeching Owles, and Batts, there pay my broken thoughts unto thy Ghost Valesco: Eccho shall wake and midnight, to help me Curse their souls that thrust thee to thy grave, whilst I will hang about Nights neck until the Moon do wake to Rescue her.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Dessandro? You must not be angry my Power came short— of my desires to serve you; We'l try some other way: You see by what Engins the Times move; The King refers all to his Council; and though they do not tie his hands, they hold 'em by a strange Courtesie: I'm but a single Looker on: Perhaps
they may take notice of me for his Brother; that's when they please too: But this came neerest to me, upon the engagement of my honour to deny my friend, and one whose single Faith had been enough for all the Kingdomes safety, the holding of such a Trifle as the Cittadel.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: It has recompens'd me in part to know where that Close annoy lay which wounded me ith' dark: I shall now collect my self against it, and know My Lord, where my poor life and powers are to be prostrate: Could I enlarge them to my wish they might appear Sir, to your Highnesse use.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I know how far you can, bravest Man; your worth has taken fire here, where Ile preserve it in a Noble Flame.— My greatest thirst of Fame is my expression to Men of your Merit, who cannot want A friend whilst I have power to be one: But I am scanted and weakned in my desires, else Fam'd Valesco had not yet slept in his dust to please the Common hangman, nor Men of glorious Parts live shrowded in obscute homes, like pamphlets out of date.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: You are the Patron of our honored Actions, and all their Glory meets and Circles in your Fame.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I will disengage you from this forc't complement; It keeps me at too great a distance from that bosome, where I would Lodge a friend, Dessandro: I must tak't unkindly too, that in the Scrowle of all your Friends, I stand dasht out a stranger to your Joys.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: But you shall not steal the Day so: I'll be one at the Ceremony, though the Bride tell me in a blush, I came unwisht for.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p:
'Tis but the busie voyce, that like the Night-mare rides men; And can find strange Shapes and prodigies.
ith' Clouds: I must Confess, Cleara has the engagement of all Her virtues and a Brothers on me; When it concerns me neerer, it must not be A Secret to your Highness, to whom all thit's deriv'd to my Poor life and Fortune is a Just debt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You know the way unto a Friend, If you can think I have power enough to make me so.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: Sir I was only shewed to the world to be talkt on: Fortune (I thank her) has given me many knacks to play with in her mood, but taken um away again scurvily, to tell me, I was not born to any real Purpose, And I wish nothing she can give me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: She will acknowledge her mistake, and Put on her smiles to Court your merits. La Gitterne? Is the King come from's sport?

sp.speaker: La Gitt.
sp.p: He dines abroad, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Collonel, this Day you shall bestow on mee: I owe the Dutchels Claudilla a visit; Make ready straight; we'l spend a dinner time there, and the afternoon at Tennis.

div.stage: That done, Claudilla and De Flame discovered sitting in a rich Couch; at each end a Lady waiting.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: This does but find our Melancholy out and cast it in a Minutes Trance; when one soft Accent from Claudilla's voice leaves nought that's earth about me. My Souls in her Elizium and every Sense immortal, dilated into joyes: Heaven becomes attentive, and the soft Winds put on their perfum'd Wings to hover neer those Lips: That Blush does shew the Sparkles of some incensed thought; My poor expressions Rob ye; But I appeal to this white hand for pardon.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Sir, my thoughts are all acknowledgments of that delight I hear and see you with, what dress so e're you please
to send your Courtship in to try um: We have outliv'd those Arts, and Common Charmes, and need not seek our hearts in scatter'd Flames, as those, whose Lesson yet, is at the hand or eye; our hearts have read Loves deep Divinity, and all his amorous Volumes over; We must write Stories of our Love, my Lord.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: And chaste ones, Madam: How glorious the Frontispiece would shew with great Claudilla's Name, ty'd in a true Loves knot to her De Flames: Though the great distance of your shining Attributes both of Blood and Virtue, consider'd in the poverty of mine, would draw squint eyes, and Envie to my stars; but speak your Name Creat as the example of your goodnesse, and make it worth the imitation of all Noble minds that shall but read your Love and sweetnesse; which (most excellent of your Sex) Condescended unto me, who else had Languish'd in a heap of Ashes.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: My Lord; you have found an easie way into my heart, and won me from my self e're I could call my thoughts to resistance; Such strength brought your Deserts: But now I hope, nay can be Confident (best Sir) they are treasur'd in a Breast, whose Virtues will preserve them with themselves.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Oh Madam!

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: It may be some Discourse, that when first I entertain'd your Love, I had not yet given the world, and my dead Husbands Earth, a full accompt of sorrow, or paid his memory a years just rent of Tears: But I appeal to my own heart; and you my Lord can say—

sp.speaker: De Flame.
Claudilla.
sp.p: True Sir.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Tears are but shallow murmurs of our Grief. I envy not his Grave a Tear, but owe all Noble mention to't; yet Madam, I did hope You had discharged the smart and Cruelty of Grief from your soft breast: And would call your beauties to their Natural springs:— Look on your self (rare Lady) in this change With what high Flame and Rapture it becomes you: So breaks the Morning forth of a christal Cloud; And so the Sun ascends his glittering Chair, And from his burnisht Locks shakes day about; The Summer puts not on more delights and various Glory, than shines in bright Claudilla; And shall the Grave exhaust their pride and Youth?—

sp.speaker: Torguina.
sp.p: Madam, the Kings Brother gives you a visit.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Who's with 'em?

sp.speaker: Torg.
sp.p: The Collonel, your Lordship calls Friend.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Dessandro?

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Let's meet 'um Sir.—

div.head: Actus Secundus, Scena Prima.
div.stage: Enter the Duke, Dutchesse, Cleara, De Flame, Dessandro, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I'm in Arrears yet unto your Grace.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: A Widows entertainment Sir, you please to honour.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I wish the hours but short that brings the Night
you are to lose that Name in; And then, to what Length your own desires woo'd spin um: Widow, Madam? Ther's disconsonancy in the Name, me thinks: Claudilla Widow? Dutchesse, and still Widow (like a Cypresse cast or'e a bed of Lillies) darkens your other Titles; 'Tis a weed in your Garden, and will spoil the Youth and beauty it grows nigh: A word of Mortality, or a Memento Mori, to all Young Ladies: And a Passing Bell to Old ones: Indeed, it is a meer Privation; and all Widows are in the state of Out-lawes, till Married again.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Your Highness holds a merry opinion of us Poor Widows.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: I say Virgins are the Ore; Widows the Gold try'd, and Refin'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: A Fair young Lady and Widow, is A rich piece of Stuff Rumpled: An Old one's A blotting Paper: A Man shall never write any thing on, she sinks so. Dessandro? your Comment.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Friend, you are dull oth' sudden.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: He is not well.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Not well, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Not well Madam.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Dull? Shall's to Tennis? I have sore Pissollets will pay your borrowed time, Dessandro.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
De Flame.
sp.p: Ha? A Physician with all speed; Dessandro?

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Dear Sir?

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Cleara? Lend me thy hand—So— I'm struck upon a Rock.—

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: He's dead; I shall not overtake him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Look to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
He swells like a stopt Torrent, or a Teeming Cloud;
Have I no Servants there?—

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: What a sudden storm is fall'n?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How fares the Lady?

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: As you are tender Natur'd, let no hand Close his eyes but mine: I am come back thus far to take my farewel on his cold Lip.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Sister, Let thy warm blood flow back: Thy Dessandro lives, my Girle.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Oh! may I not see him?

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: You shall.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Give me leave to make this opportunity happy on your hand: How? Not vouchsafe it?

What a Tyranny shot from her scornful eye? Where have I lost my self and her? There's a crosse, and Peevish Genius haunts my Hopes; A Black and envious Cloud; and I must get above it; Not kisse your hand? Is your blood surfeited? I'le quit this scorn: Indeed, I will, Coy Madam: Thou, that art Lord of my proud Horoscope; Great Soul of Mysteries; kindle my brain with thy immortal fires— That if I fall, my Name may Rise Divine, So Casar's Glory set, and so set Mine.—

div.stage: Enter Silliman, a Bottle tyed in a Ribbon to his Pocket.

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: Brave Canary; Intelligent Canary, that does refresh our weak and mortal bodies; I will have thee Canoniz'd Saint Canary, at my own Charge: And call my eldest Son Canary: Yet for a man to love thee at his own Cost is damnable, very Damnable, and I defie it— And Siss is the blithest Lasse in our Town For she sells Ale by the Pound and the Dozen; Ale? hang Ale.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p:
By your Worships leave, I wou'd speak with
Seign'or Silliman, the Dutchesse Steward, an't like ye.

sp.speaker: Silli.
sp.p: Wou'd you speak with Seignior Silliman, an't like ye?

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p: Please God, and your Worship, an't like ye.

sp.speaker: Sill.
sp.p: In what Language wou'd you speak with him—

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p: Yes verily, I wou'd speak with him, an't like ye.

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: At what Posture?

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p: Marry from a friend, an't like ye.

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: Very good, my friend: Didst ever say thy
Prayers in the Canary tongue?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: My Prayers, an't like ye? Your Worship's dispos'd to be merry: I have a Wife and seven small Children, an't like ye, to wind, and turn, as they say, simple as your Worship sees me here, an't like ye.

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: Pox a Wives; I'le not give a Gazet for thy wife; she's tough, and too much Powder'd: Fetch me thy Daughter, thy youngest Daughter, Sirrah, If the Creature be a Virgin and desirable: Look ye! There's money to buy her Clean Linen: I'le have a Bath of rich Carnary, and Venus milk, where we will bath, and swim together, like so many Swans, and then be Call'd Seignior Jupiter Sillimano. But is she Mans meat? I have a tender Appetite, and can scarcely digest one in her Teens.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: Do's your worship think I wou'd be a Judas, an't like ye? She's as neat a Girle, and as Tite at her businesse as the back of your hand, an't like ye: But Heaven blesse ye, and Cry ye mercy: If you be his Worship here's a Letter from the Lady De Prate, an't like ye.

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: The Lady De Prate (mark me Sirrah) is a Noble Lady; we say so.—

I never knew what Bondage was till now, I fear the Gilded Hart you sent me was inchanted—(oh—oh) I long to see you— —(hum—hum) therefore let me have the happinesse to know the Place and Time—(even so) as you love her that blushes to write this—
Yes, yes, I'le Inchant ye: I'le Time and Place ye: Surely, there's something more about me, then I can perceive: Grant that I may bear my Fate discreetly: I never knew what Bondage was—
till now: Well; 'Tis Heavens Goodnesse: For what am I silly wretch, to such a Lady as she that writes so pitifully unto me: It wou'd over-come e'en a heart
of Flint: Good Gentlewoman— As you love her that blushes to write this—
hum—yes, yes; she knows I love her: It will work—I can't contain my good nature.—

div.stage: Enter La Gitterne, and De Loome.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Here he is, and stands like a Map of sundry Countries.

sp.speaker: La Gitterne.
sp.p: One wou'd take him for some forraign beast, and that Fellow to shew him; how the Gander Ruffles and Prunes himself, as if he would tread the Goose by him?

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: 'Tis a pure Goat.

sp.speaker: La Gitt.
sp.p: And will clamber a Pyramide in sent of's Female.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: The Wenches sware he kisses like a Giant still, and will ride his heats as Cleanly, as a dieted Gelding: Let's fall in: Seignior Silliman! My best wishes kisse your hand.

sp.speaker: La Gitt.
sp.p: Continue me worthy the Title of your Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: I am very glad to see you well, and hope you are in good health, and sound Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: La Gitterne.
sp.p: And when shall's draw Cutts again for a Wench, Seignior, hah?

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: Your pleasure to say so.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: The Slave's rose drunk, o' my life.

sp.speaker: Sill.
sp.p: Please you to take Notice of my worthy Friend here.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Your Admirer, Sir.

sp.speaker: La Gitterne.
sp.p: Slave to your Sedan, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: God blesse the good Dutchess, and all that love the King, I say Gentlemen, an't like ye.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Pray Sir, what News abroad, or at Court?

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p:
News, quoth a? Indeed Sir, the truth is, I am a
Shooemaker by my Trade; My Name is Latchet; And I work to some Ladies in the House here, though I say't my self; And yet the Times were never harder, nor Leather dearer.

sp.speaker: De Loom.
sp.p: This winter will make amends; you shall have horse hides cheap; horse hides, dog cheap.

sp.speaker: Latchet.
sp.p: Cheap? quoth a; Why Sir, I'le tell you (for you look like a very honest Gentleman) I am put to finde a Pike my self; and must, the Parish swears, or lose all the Shooes in my Shop.

sp.speaker: De Loom.
sp.p: 'Tis very brave: Why you look like a Champion And have a Face, the Parish may Confide in.

sp.speaker: Latchet.
sp.p: Fide? quoth a; Sir; be Judge your self, if ever you knew the like: I have been at the Trade this forty years, off and on: and those Childrens shooes I have sold for six pence, or a groat, upon some occasion, we now sell for twelve pence, as they say.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Then the misery is, you get the mo • e.

sp.speaker: Latchet.
sp.p: More? quoth a; Pray Sir a word? you are a Courtier, if I may be so bold: They say we must all be fain to shut up shop, and mortgage our Wives to the Souldiers: D' ye hear any such talk, Sir?

sp.speaker: De Loom.
sp.p: Some buzzing: but the blades will not accept'um without special articles, and a stock of money, and plate to keep the babies they shall beget valiant.

sp.speaker: Latchet.
sp.p: Valiant? quoth a; Truly Sir, I'le tell ye, on the truth of a poor man: My Lady De Prates foot is but of the sixes; and yet we pay five Pistols A Dicker.

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: My Ladies foot but oth' sixes? you lye Sirrah; By Saint Hugh, there's never a Lady ith' Land has a Prettier Foot and Leg, if you ha not spoil'd um with your Calves skin, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: La Gitt.
sp.p: Why? the sixes is a good han'som size for a Lady.

sp.speaker: Latchet.
sp.p: Lady? quoth a; my life for hers, there's few Ladies ith' Court goes more upright: Nor payes better, I'le say that.

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: You say that? Foh; I scorn to wear an inch of leather thy Nasty flesh shall handle.

sp.speaker: De Loom
Latchet.
sp.p: Trust? quoth a; My Name's Latchet, Sir, I serv'd Eleven years to my Vocation, before I could be free: and have drank many a good bowl of Beerith' Dutchesses Cellar, since that.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: I like a man can answer so punctually to a thing,

sp.speaker: Latchet.
sp.p: Thing? quoth a; It is our Trade, Sir.

sp.speaker: De Loom.
sp.p: Spoke like the Warden of the Company.

div.stage: Enter Claudilla, and Dessandro in a Night Gown.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: I am at extremity of wonder.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: The story may deserve it Lady, when you shall Cast your thoughts upon the Man it Treats on, the Circumstances, and progresse of my Love: Nay, it may raise your Anger bigher than your wonder, and work the modest pantings of your breast into a Hectique Rage: I saw this tempest gather'd in a Cloud dismal and black, ready to break its wombe in stormes upon me: And I have cast my Soul on every Frown and horror you can arm your passion with: I have held conflict with the wilder Guilt and tremblings of my blood to rescue it: But Heaven, and my angry Fate, has thrown me groveling at your feet: And I want soul to break the Charm.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: This is a strange Mystery, to betray my virtue with your own, and I shall sin to hear it.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: If pity be a sin, lock up those beauties from the view of men, or they will damn all the eyes that look upon you.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Has your blood lost all the virtue it should inherit? And think you by this treacherous siege to take my Honour in? Let me shun you, or you will talk me Leperous.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p:
Do Madam—
Tear up the wounds your eyes have made— Ile keep them bleeding Sacrifices to your Cruelty; And when cold death has cast his gloomy shade o're this dust, perhaps you may bestow one gentle sigh to hallow it; when you shall know The height of my desires was but to dye worthy of your pardon, without the ambition of a bolder thought; And still had scorch'd, and smother'd here without a Tongue, only to beg your mercy to my Grave.

sp.speaker: Claudil.
sp.p: Play not your self into a shame will rust your brightest worths, and hide your Dust in Curses, and black Fame: I now shall think your valour Flatter'd, that can sink it to such effeminate and Love sick Crafts for our stale Women to mollifie the Usher with. Dessandro has a Fame, high and active as the voice it Flies on: And could you wander from your religious self in such a Dream as this? Cleara's virtue has an Interest neer your heart should wake you to your first man again.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: Cleara still is here in the first Sculpture of her virtues, and I their honourer.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: No more!— My grief and shame are passionate to find so much bad man, got neer your heart, and shew this sick Complexion in your honour, more tainted then the Face of your Imposture— you have plaid the excellent counterfeit, and your skill does make you proud, you cannot blush.—

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: She's gone;— A Star shot from her eye, and lightned through my blood: I must provide for Thunder, and thy Revenge De Flame, as horrid as thought can shape it.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Proud Love? I'll meet thee with burning sighes and bleeding Turtles at thy shrine.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: This is too bold a hazzard for your health, which yet sits wan and troubled on your Cheek.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Indeed I'll chide ye.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Oh, Cry ye mercy;—some retired meditations.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: I shall observe 'um, Let me but leave you with the Joy to know I stand not in the hazzard of that Frown.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: We'll kisse next time.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Or never.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Ha? de'e know me?

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: So well, me thinks we should not part so soon: our hearts have been more ceremonious, and hung in panting sighs upon our Lips to bid adieu: one kisse must now summe up all, and seal their General Release: I know Cleara more constant to her virtue, and brave mind, then to ask heaven idle questions—'Tis Fate, not Will—

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: So— I feel thy Marble hand lye here: 'Tis cold and heavy: how my poor heart throbs under it, and struggles to find Air? Not one kind sigh lend thee a gale for yonder haven?—It's gone— Quite vanisht—beshrew me, it was a most horrible apparition, I wou'd not see it again in such a cruel look for all my hopes; yet it held me gently by the hand, and left a warm farewell there, as my Dessandro us'd: As my Dessandro? said I? oh! how fain my hopes would mock my apprehension; and that my sorrow? I'le woe thy pity with my Groans kind earth, and lay my throbbing breast to thine until I am dissolv'd into a Spring, whose Murmures shall eternally repeat this Minutes story.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Ha?—

sp.speaker: Cleara
sp.p: drown'd in her own Tears? Sister? Cleara?

sp.speaker: Cleara
sp.p: I had a gentle slumber; and all the world (me thought) was in • midnight Calm.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Dear Girl. 〈◊〉 up those sad eyes & my cold doubts. Prethee tell me, is our Dessandro dead?

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Heaven defend.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Not? what then in all the volumes of black destiny and nature, can throw you into this posture?— Unkind Cleara; why dost dissemble it? I see him breathlesse on thy Cheek, and lost.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Lost for ever.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: My fears did prompt me so; For ever?— there's horrour and amazement in the thought: See Cleara; my eyes can over-take thee: Gone at so short a farewel friend? Death, thou art the murderer of all our joyes and hopes.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Sir, Dessandro's well; very well; we parted even but now.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Oh Brother? I have lost a jewell that he gave me and I shall vex my eyes out.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Beshrew this serious folly: you have vext my blood into a sullen fit.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: You shall not chide me— Tell me? didst ever in thy life meet with a Grief that made thy poor heart sick, and did divide thy sleeps and hours into groans and sighs?

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Never; thank my indifferent Fate.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Nor in the Legend of some Injur'd Maid that made thine eye to pause, and with a Tear bedew it.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: I cannot untie Ridled knots, Cleara.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Come; I'le but dry mine eyes, and tell you a story that shall deserve a groan.—

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p:
TUsh— They had only tongue & malice; and that great Zeal
the seem'd to owe to Rome, was unto themselves, and their own Estates; what were they, but wranglers in Schools and Law? and studied words to make men guilty. They liv'd at ease; and slept in purples and warm furrs; But bold minded Cataline, threatned their wise sleeps.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: There was too much attempt and fact in't.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: 'Twas fact then to look sowre on a Gown-man: they were meer Citizens: Jealous of their Wives, and Daughters: That Condemn'd um too:—

sp.speaker: De Castro!
sp.p: there's a Lethargy in our blood: We sleep and dream away our Lives. If such wore purple for well talking, what shal he merit that Cures the wounds and smart his Country groans with?

sp.speaker: De Cast.
sp.p: The People shall enshrine his Name with Reverence, and fill their Temples with his Statues: 'Tis the great end we are all born to.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Which can't be, whilst by-respect shall closely wound the bosome of our Laws and Freedome: For what was't Lesse, that took our Father's life?

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: In whose blow, the heads of all brave men were threatned.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Then if we dare not do a general good, yet let us secure our own dear lives and honours.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: The State is full of dangerous whispers.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: There's an Impostume swells it.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: Wou'd 'twere lanc'd.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Spoken with the soul of Cassius; we have the cure, and may do it with a little stir: But then we must deal like true Physicians of State, And where we find it ulcer'd, though in our selves, friends, and allies, not lay soft effeminate hands on't: Nature has made us nearest to our selves: And I wou'd pay the last warm drop of blood from all these veins to see the hopes and honours of our blood (that's now benightned in our Fathers fate) dawn on De Castro's youth again.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p:
No Dessandro; Those hopes are lost upon a high
and angry sea: And I must see fools and stale Parasites (whose Progeny ne're bled one drop, nor had a valiant thought to serve their Country) begin A spurious Issue on my birth-right, that will, on Tiptoes Collossus like, bestride us and graspe our Fate.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Take me into thy bosome, brave man; we meet Like Amorous streams, and as we ought; our honour, life, and fortunes, have but one hea • t: Give me thy hand De Castro; This Sword—

our Father h • th oft made Glorious in the blood of De Castro's foes: And I'll not doubt, how much it prompts thy valiant soul: Oh Brother! Tears, and some sad discourse is all that we have paid him yet: Strangers can be far braver in their sence unto his Fame: The tears we ought to shed, ought to be blood, De Castro; Blood, warm from their veins, that made us weep in streams, and mingle it with the dust of vulgar feet, as they did his. Swear by all the Glorious acts of our great Ancestry, their hallowed Urnes, our Fathers injur'd memory, and all the hopes and honour we derive from them, to pay his blood a sad accompt in some revenge, worthy his Ghost, and our bold hands.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: All which religiously, I vow to.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: And I: So; Now we are Brothers by as strong Divinitie as Nature: I'll not break open the design, till we shall hear't confirm'd by higher warrant: Anon, meet at the Dutchesse Dowager's.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: Claudilla's?

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Yes, where you shall hear something worthy the encouragement of our Fathers spirit in thee: I am now to wait upon the Duke; he that keeps us what we are.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: The Duke?—I have the Game in view, and now discern, what I must pay him for my Place.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: You are full of thoughts, my Lord.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p:
Brother, our Lives are on the Cast: But 'tis not that does interpose 'um: There's something in my fears
still presents Cleara; Take heed Dessandro—A Virgins tears leave sad and Fatal prints.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Your wishes are a brothers: but those dreams chill not my sleeps: Think on that concerns us near And be Active.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: I shall not fail ye: Farewel.—

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: Collonel Dessandro?

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Your Lordships pardon: Which way walk you?

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: As you please to dipose me: My businesse now defigns it so: 'Tis there in short—

I love his gallant mastery of a mans self: I look'd his temper wou'd a flam'd about my ears: Not a sparkle in his brow, nor the least change of blood. Strange! I have seen him ruffl'd into a storm, and all fury: Now, not a frown nor smile.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: De Flame?—well— My Lord, this is a down flat Challenge.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: I brought it for one.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: I accept it, with thanks to your Lordship, and shall be ready to serve you in any power I have.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: 'Tis not worth it, Collonel.

sp.speaker: Dess
sp.p: The Lord De Flame's angry, it seems that fortune should give me right without his hand in't, h'as turn'd his style high and strangely on me: But I shall coolly respite that, till we have room to argue it. That he is far more worthy his expectation in the Dutchesse, I can Confesse: that's no assent Sir to my quarrel; nor yet a law to her: For those whom her thoughts please to think most worthy, are so to her.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: But does not bind the opinion of another.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Nor that opinion her Freedome.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: Yet there be rules in virtue, from which all noble Judgements should take their Level, even in love it self.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: If it be thought she's too partial in her grace to me, I shall dispute it, as 'tis questioned.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: I come not to add exceptions or to make any.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p:
I stand not in so cheap a Rank, but that her
favour may make my services as meritorious as his Lordships: And can engage as much blood and Fame for't.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: You know him of a Noble breast, and one that will not slatter weak pretences into Truths, nor let um work with such impressions on his Soul, did not his Honour bleed in't? Sir, I come as one that ever honour'd your great parts, and wish that you could think on't o're again: Think how black you must expect that morn to rise upon your wishes, When you lead her to the Altars; where the faint Lights with blew and Gastly Flames, will receive ye; And all the things of Holy Ceremony Present pale Glim'rings to your eyes, to fright your Bride back unto her first vows: And then, me thinks, each Tear and Groan the Fair Cleara lends to over-take ye, shou'd shew a speaking Fury to untwine your trembling hands.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: No; Nor all the squadrons hell can spare, to aid them: though her Brother led them on, and you brought up the Rear.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Pish—The meanest thought Claudilla pleases to bestow here (under this humble Guard) must be without the affright (my Lord) of all the dangers in his Muster: Stare they like Giants on me, and in Armies: As for Cleara, If she held flatering glasses to her thoughts which render'd um wide and Airy, they must not forfeit me: you may deserve her better: I'le not start Sir a scruple from his demands, and yours, expect it, and so farewell.—

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: Farewell?—The Time?

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: I shall think on't.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: Shall?—It must not so tamely be thought on.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: I spoke it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Are your sent to own the Quarrel?

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: No; but look on't with so much Soul, as I think't as honour to wear a Sword in't.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Go; Go hang it in your Mistresses Chamber, It stink▪ Sir of Perfume.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: It may Sir (for Destiny has many wayes to the wood) Cut your throat; And then Ile giv't your Foot-boy.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: My throat, Pirez? that sawcy thought has ruin'd thee.—

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Collonel.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: My Lord, y'are hurt.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: I must owe him this fort't.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Canst talk yet?

sp.speaker: Samp.
sp.p: Command your passion: See how the Common herd come Gazing in: do not become their talk and wonder: Noble Dessandro? Put up my Lord: —thank ye—

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Sir, my Lord Duke sent me to tell ye he expects your Company.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: I wait on him—bid the Ladies tear their clean smocks to wrap you in.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: Insolent Man.

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: Again?—
Was not I about to tell you so? they wou'd be afraid of True men when we came.
Ber Lady, but that mun not serve their Turns; For we must know flatly which was Plantan, & which Defendam or we shall discharge but a sorry Conscience to the Kings Justice.
I'll take my Oath upon the Corporal Bible, I saw two glittering Swords run a Tilt, and two to that, if need be.

Neighbors, I cannot tell; we are old men, or shou'd be at least; some of us have lived threescore years and upwards in a Parish, as they say, I name no body; and
therefore it is good to be sure, & make all our tales bonum fidrum▪
For we are not all one mans Children: And yet, if I be not mistaken, I am sure I saw three more, and Glittering ones indeed, as you call them: God bless every good man and woman from the like: they e'en earn'd my heart, and yet by my Fay, I am a hundred and two, come the time.

You tawke like sucking Infants: Neighbours, I'll be sworn If I were to take my oath before the best man living, High or low, there was twenty drawn swords, little and great; I'm sure, I might a seen um, like a fool, had I been worth my head; but my little boy Jack did.
La there; And that same's a murrain wise boy, if you mark him; and will see a thing, I warrant you, as soon as the wisest of us all, were he twice as old again.
I could a seen too at his bignesse, for all I'm Lame now, God help us; you remember the Powder Plot.
Powder Plot? quoth a; I shall not forget while the world stands.
Nor I, were I to die a thousand deaths.
That very day was I working in our Garret.
Say you so?
Nay, Neighbours beshrew me this may be true, for I have known this man here, able to do as tite a dayes work by noon, as the tallest fellow the King keeps (God blesse him) take him from top to toe.

All's one for that; mark me; There has not been a glasse-window there, time out of mind, since I came, nor after: And I tell you truely (I'm a false Liar else) I smelt the Powder as hot as if it had been done the next day.
See, see, the wind; the wind neighbours is much God blesse us.

Go too; I am no made fool, though a born fool my Masters; True, the wind may be something as you say: but if there had not been something else, I wou'd not give a fart for't: I did not work at Court with a Master Carpenter, for nothing, my boyes; and see the Kings Grace fasting and full
as I did, to a hairs breadth, as they say: Let me alone for Casting my Cards, give me but ground enough; And yet I can neither write nor read, Heaven make me thankful.
Heaven make us all thankful; I have seen the King too, in my Prime, and gave him a beck upon his milk-white Steed, as near as one shud say what's this, and all his Royal Lords and Ladies sporting.
I, I, those were the dayes (peace be with um) a poor mans tale might be heard at Court: There is some Lords and Ladies now, were lowsie then.
Go thy wayes, by the Rood; Nay, he'l have his old tawk, for all the world, up and down.

It was ever my condition; I care not who knows it; And yet I never scath't the least sucking Child that begs his bread: but little does another man know where the Kings shooe wrings him, but those that wear it, as my Mother would often say, and she liv'd long enough to know it.

Nay that's certain; The King's but a Man, as we three are; No more is the Queen, if you go to that: Did you never hear of my Uncles observations? he's but a poor knave (as they call him) but such a knave as Cares neither for King nor Kaesar, the Least on um.
Then he may be hanged, Neighbour Palmer.
If he be, he's not the first that has been hang'd for Treason, I hope.

sp.speaker: Duke.
Claud.
sp.p: You'l sully your honour in't: widows are but rumpl'd stuff.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: That again? by all my hopes, and by thy self, the next and greatest—

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Your Brothers Crown's betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I did it but to sharp De Flame, into some
expression of his Wit and Love.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Alas! he sighs all.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: And like some Crude Chaplain, spits most of his mind.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
Duke.
sp.p: Now he can come to hand:—ha, ha▪ thinking men never Love heartily, unlesse they be dank Powder.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: His Courtship is like thick Embroidery upon slight stuff. I must confesse, I never lov'd the man; onely as a Rich Gown out of Fashion, for a dayes change sometimes at home when I take Physick.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You may wear him as you please, and to what purpose; his honest nature was meant you so: but Dessandro is the Man of Men (I must confesse) that I could wish most near you now.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Dessandro!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: And suddenly, before your honour blush too palpably: I have discovered him, and his devotions.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Then your brains was in his Plot.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: 'Twas his own.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Stolen from some Romance or Play, but for De Flame.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: One wheel will move another to the Period.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Methinks his soft and easie spirit should be the fitter Engin, and more pliant to your Aim.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: He has too much of Venus in his mixture; all his desires wou'd be at home still, in the circle of those eyes: the other is all Fire and thinks that Fame too cheap that's found so near; And there will want such men abroad.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: But, where's my honour, Duke?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Lock'd in my heart and Cares: the King must die Claudilla, to smooth the way, and lift us to our wishes.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: That still is talk'd on.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
His last Glasse is now turn'd, and runs apace:
He gives thee to Dessandro; and is your Guest: and that Night receives eternal thanks for't: Then (my Fair) Dessandro cannot want lustre and honour for your bed: Nor thy commands what all Castile can give.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: I understand not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Thou shalt in time; oh my Claudilla! my best and neerest Joy, our Loves have been entire as a flame: one Center to our thoughts and wishes, and Crown our bosomes with delight and safety—but they are come—

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: I have not known so little of his Fame— to be a stranger to his worth: Sir I honour it: Nor am I so proud and dark in my opinion, to think I stand upon my self, but stoop in honour to one of his deserts and blood: This is the way, my Lord, I ever sum'd up Man, and sets his Titles down but for Cyphers.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: Observe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Which will most clearly shew his merits, and heighten them in value to you: For, Madam, look on him in the Spring of his deserts, and you'l say, Titles are but narrow Spheres: And if honoured actions be the soul and breath, he's then above them and stands in the First Rank of men.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: I shall want life to pay this debt.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: But with your Graces favour, I must be tender here, For I stand a tall Mark to Voice and Censure, and need not tell your Highnesse with what strong expectation the Count De Flame hath long time visited me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: If you will stand engaged, Madam— I am silent.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: No Sir—But—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
You expect honour, and Fortune to your Bed: I know Castile ownes not a Subject (I'll not except my self, and had I anothers Freedome, I should not speak my wishes in a second person) that
Looks not with Ambition on you: But Madam, weigh them all: Take but off their Grains of fortune he shall hoist them into the air: And to my wish, he's come—Dessandro, your name was mentioned happily, I hope—Let me present his value, to your Graces hand: And to a Sister, Madam, I wou'd say, her bosome.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: You purchase our poor Lives too highly, Sir

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I wou'd have rich Jewels set to their worth, and shall be proud to give any advantage unto his: The Dutchesse shall not slight me in't: I will be heard against the proudest Courtship that shall charm her. Come my Lord, what sport will you win some Duckats at?

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: I will lose some at any your Grace pleases.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: My Brother has got a fortunate hand of late 'gainst all the Court: I cannot rise at even terms from him.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: I saw him draw deep from your Grace, last night.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Two thousand Duckats; but I expect um with interest again.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: I cannot pawn my self to the unworthy ends of Flattery and Complement: but this honour out-bids value of a thousand Lives: what this poor glimpse of expression can shew me in: Saints, are not more unfained in their prayers, then I to serve you.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: I shall not doubt how much I may be indebted to your Noble wishes: but let me add, Sir, He that Layes out for me without my warrant, shall scarcely put it on my accompt for thanks, much lesse, Debt.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Not good devotions?

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Them I desire, and shall repay.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Then pay back mine.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: I'm not to learn my prayers, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Teach me yours, that I may turn the virtue of their charms back to your bosome.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Collonel, mine wou'd hardly please you: I never pray for wars.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You have back-friends, my Lord.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: That some malignant cloud does interpose the Kings cheerful Favour, I am most sensible.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: It wou'd spread to me too, if they durst.

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: Had they but so much virtue left, they durst own their names by, I shou'd make pale envy blush.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Come, we'll to Cards; and leave them to parl.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Madam, but mean it in a smile.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Love.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Fie.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Yet stay; The air has busie wings: but give the thought Consent: and I will take it in soft whispers from your Lip.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: You will.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: I feel it creep in Flames through all my blood.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Sir, the Count De Flame.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: With a black Evening in his face.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Oh! my faithful Achilles, I came to give you Joy.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Who? me, Sir!

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: My virtuous friend, and you.

sp.speaker: Claudilla,
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: De Fl.
sp.p: Of your entertainment under him: y'have a brave Commander and he a—I cannot be angry enough to tell you what.

sp.speaker: Claudilia.
sp.p: I begin to doubt his Wits, he looks so Gastly.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Yes; I see a Devil in those eyes that makes my hair. stare upward, False woman: My love durst scarce doubt before, what now I find, and tremble at. But Heaven has wrath in Ambush, and Scorpions stings.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: For what? my Lord.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Dutchesse, thy Perjury, and warm engagements to this—this huge Impostor.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Sir, a has Crack'd his brains with Poetry— pray forgive him—

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: Count? you know what privilege this Roof can give you, on my Anger; or else, I should make your Frenzy Tonguelesse: Don't requite it barbarously on her that gives you leave to live by it: gather your scatter'd wits up: Goe home Sir, and Repent.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Privilege?— I'le, meet thee in a Ring of flames, or on the Tempest of some billow, upon whose back the raging North wind strides: Yet I'de not ha' thee lose one spark of thy full man in Noise and Air: that when next we greet, I may find thee worthy my Revenge. This Frailty, now protects thee.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Uncivill man! know the way back, or I shall let that Justice loose upon yee, you deserve.

sp.speaker: De Fl.
sp.p: Your Centaure there, you mean; he must stare bigger to move a hair of mine.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Yee sha' not stir, Sir: As you love me do not: Let him die Mad.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Do; kisse him; and clap his Cheek.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: And circle him in my Arms from your Pale envy; does that make you some—Look yee—

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: He shall not blossome there.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: A shall, though thou dost bribe the Fayries with thy soul.

sp.speaker: Dess.
sp.p: Madam, your Commands will hold me till I scorch away; I am in Flames, and Torment: And there's not so much mercy under heaven, but your own, would let him use that Tongue a minute longer. Thou hast seen this Sword reeking from Hilt to Point, and sweating showres of Blood o're thy head, whil'st I bestrid thy life and Rescu'd it 'gainst many gallant Foes, And durst thou tempt it to thine own throat now? Prethee begone; And let's meet no more There's something in thy youth I still can love; and will forget to call thee to accompt for this; be wise unto thy self; And ask this Lady Pardon.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Oh my Blood! must I bear this? I am more cold then Marble sure.

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Within there? where's his Grace?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: At Cards, Madam.

sp.speaker: De Fla.
Dessandro.
sp.p: 'Tis there again, and has stop'd the use I took it for.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Ha?—I'll make thy Name a boys Play, and kill thee on the threshold of thy dore.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Goe, goe, and take your Rest: when you are recovered, I may own you.

sp.speaker: De Fl.
sp.p: Thou hast not Blood enough to answer this—

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: You tell me strange ones.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: But true ones.

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: Nice windings.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: This Duke can strangely back his purposes where they like him: 'Tis a fair lift to Dessandro's fortune: his stars shin'd.

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: True; sh'has a spacious Fortune; But I shall tell your Lordship, what perhaps you know not.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: You may.

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: She has no blood: From her first, an honest Trades-mans wife, who left her very rich and handsome: The Duke (as he still keeps a kennell for that purpose) had her presented to him for his Game: Remov'd her from the Cucko'os nest into another Sphere, but with all Caution, and private slight: And you must Imagine, now she spreads a larger wing stirs not abroad, but studded like the Night, with Flames: And at length becomes the Courts discourse and wonder; but still kept the Country her retiring place.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: Unknown?

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p:
Or unsuspected, as the Dukes Instruments dealt it: And the young Henriques being in those parts
with our Kings brother for sport, casually (as 'twas plotted) visits her house: Falls in love and marryed her: This is the Epitomie.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: I hope the Duke Bereo, had no dull hand in't.

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: 'Tis thought (only by me Sir) keeps his acquaintance to this day.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: It must be Fatally answered some where; heaven has a Justice.

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: The Preparation makes huge Noise.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: 'Tis well the King's a Guest; Their Triumph might miscarry else.

sp.speaker: Sampayo:
Pirez.
sp.p: It must be put to an Accompt somewhere.

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: To return his Challenge and honour with such a scorn must work such a spirit to high extremes.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: The saddest story is his Sister.

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: A Rose new Blown, and flung aside to wither in her sweets; Poor Innocence; That has much chang'd my opinion of Dessandro.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: His Resolution, and Ambition, are like vast Trees whose spreading tops hide their own Roots from the kind Sun.

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: Let out unto so vast a Pride, as shades all his natural virtues, or makes 'um grow up rank and sower: The event will tell us all.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: I wish it without blood. Your Lorships for the Solemnity?

sp.speaker: Sampayo.
sp.p: My Attendance ties me to his Majesties Person.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: My best wishes to your Lordship.

div.head: Actus Quartus, Scena Prima.
div.stage: Enter the King, Cardinall, Duke, Dutchesse, Dessandro, De Castro, Sampayo, Ladies bearing up her Train, Voices, Lutes, they passe over, Manet De Loome and La Gitterne.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: SO: By this time the confines Ring of our great Solemnity.

sp.speaker: La Git.
sp.p: She became his hand bravely, & with so skilful a brow, as if the first Fruits of her honour, were to be gathered yet.

sp.speaker: De Loom.
sp.p: Our Duke will lick his Lips at this nights sport.

sp.speaker: La Gitternt.
sp.p: And wind her up for him, 'twill go hard else.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: That shall not hinder our sport, I hope.

sp.speaker: La Git.
sp.p: Expect the Steward and his Bottles, I'le warrant you

sp.speaker: De Loom.
sp.p: The Ladies too? we shall not tickle heartily else.

sp.speaker: La Gitterne.
sp.p: When the great ones are bedded.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: I'th old Place?

sp.speaker: La Gitterne.
sp.p: It's Corner Lobby.

div.stage: Enter De Flame and Cleara disguis'd.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: You belong to the Duke De Bereo Sir?

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Who told you so?

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: A Friend that wou'd commend me with a poor suit unto you Sir, if you be Signior De Loome.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: But this is no year for suit; Sir.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Mine brings thanks ready told Sir, Look yee? All double Pistolets, Signior.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Sir, I shall try my Power, and be ready in any service te'e, for my friends sake.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: De'e know who 'tis?

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Hum—No matter; I'le undertake your businesse.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Sir, can you please to pardon some light Gold?

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: You shall find me a Gentleman in any thing for my friends sake.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Nay Sir, It weighs a hundred pound at all Peradventures.

sp.speaker: De Loom.
sp.p: And I'le tell you one thing of my self Sir, more then perhaps my friend remembred; I am very honest where I take; and every man is not to be trusted with matters of such Consequence: A very Fair purse, I assure you.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Nest and Birds are all your own.

sp.speaker: De Loom.
sp.p: Your business is done, beleev't Sir: Please you to kiss the Kings hand into the bargain?

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: At fitter opportunity, let me be ambitious of your offer: but I shall woe your Curtesie to be only a looker on now.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Any thing Sir, you can make worthy your request Nay-I hope you do not wish me forfeit
good manners—As I'm virtuous—

sp.speaker: De Fl.
sp.p: I am a stranger to the way: Gentlemen? know your selves, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: La Gitterne.
sp.p: To obey you Signior.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Sir you need not speak on't to this man: he's but my Lords Barber: Since you command it so—

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Light, light Revenge! heave up thy gloomy Tapers that thou may'st see thy smeered Altar shine in blood: Come my Cleara; my better soul, whose gallant mind will leave thy Name in the first place of Women, And raise thee Temples (bravest of thy Sex:) I could expire on thy Cheek, and pay thee reverence my most excellent Sister.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Just heaven, and your brave virtue (my dearest brother) has wak'ned my dull breast and trembling Sex: I do not feel one Pale or Coward thought: but all high, and active to my wish.

sp.speaker: De Flame.

div.stage: Enter Duke whispering with De Castro.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: The Duke—

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Now Innocence, guard thy self, the woolf is up: see how mischief teems and quickens on their brow: some black thing is spawning: Night must be Midwife to't: If we stay, my Ponyard will break loose.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: De Castro.
sp.p: Some of the Dutchesse Servants, I beleeve Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
De Castro.
sp.p: 'Tis his last night with Mankind: The Poison Sir wil doo't so subtilly: whil'st he but holds the Knife, the least warmth attracts, and so dispreads
it self through his blood and spirits. Not any strugling for't with nature: his life steals from him in a gentle slumber.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Grow in my bosome; till you spread to the first honors of your wish: My fortune is too narrow for your merits to whom I owe it, & all my Power, brave friend

div.stage: Enter Steward, Butler, Cook, and Maids.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: Come my Masters; The great ones shall not have all to themselves: wee'l have a Civil bout or two, to get us a stomach to Bedward, my sweet hearts.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Noble Mr. Steward!

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Brave Mr. Steward!

sp.speaker: Cook
sp.p: The Fire of my respects shall ne're go out unto you.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Nor mine be Quench'd.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: Here Cook? here's a bit for you to lick your Lips at And heer's clean Napery for you Butler
take it—

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: So, so; I am almost spent; every man to their Function

div.stage: Enter King, Cardinal, Dessandro, Duke, Dutchesse, Attendants.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The Night begins to frown at our uncivil stay▪ And Hymens Tapers do burn out a pace: Good Night; you shall not stir a foot Dessandro.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: All the wishes of a Bridall bed Crown your wishes and embraces.

sp.speaker: Cardinal.
sp.p: And all the blessings of true Joy

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: To bed to bed.

div.stage: Enter De Loome and De Flame.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: You are as melancholly as day when Sun sets; I hope you do not doubt my promise.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: De Loom.
sp.p:
Ye sha' not: I'll not leave you till the Grant be yours be Confident; And that's more then a Courtier is bound to by his oath. Sir, where are you? why you were living but e'en now; could speak, and sence too: ha' you seen any thing against nature, or stomach?
hum—Sweet heart, has thy Master any fits o'th Mother?
or Falling-sicknesse? Pretty knave; 'tis pity this face was made for breeches.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: I am glad you are come to your self again.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: You are pleasant.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: I wou'd ha'you so: I have provided some mirth and good company for you: Please you but spare an idle hour from your sleep, we'll allow't again in the total of your businesse (I must not lose his money) If you can smile you sha'not want a subject: besides, we shall have the wit of a handsome Lady or two, and hear their voices.
sp.stage: Enter Steward, and a Man with bottles.
sp.p: Look ye Sir! here's the Imprimis of the house Mr. Steward himself, whose Company may be worth your observation—Seigniour Silliman, this Gentleman is a friend of my Lord Dukes; pray let him know he's welcome.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: I am but the Dutchesses poor Steward Sir, but my place is at your Command, Sir: you sha'not have me Claim kindred of her for all that: yet— Sir Thomas De Loome here, can say something if he please, Sir.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Thank ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: Look ye Sir Thomas! I never fail; here be the perquisites of life and good Company: There's that will elevate voices; come, disburthen thy self, in that Lobbie, my honest rational Camel; Is this Gentleman dumb? he can say nothing but Thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: I fear he's Planet-struck.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: 'Tis great pity: yet he makes very gentle signs.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: I'm got into a dark and slippery Labyrinth, and grope but by a spark, whilst every pause is fatal —No. It had miscarried; and the Kings presence was a sacred guard: now to break in upon them, were to betray our lives to nothing: sure Heaven will not lose the glory of such a Justice, and by a hand so justly engaged.

div.stage: Enter La Gitterne, Torguina, and La Prate.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: The Ladies; Good Girles; this deserves a double thanks—Here's a Gentleman whose merits may invite him to your acquaintance, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Torguina.
sp.p: I shall ever study that due honour, by all the Ambitiousnesse of your humble Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: You may please to pardon her, whose demerits makes her modest in their expressions to honour you Noble Sir.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: You engage a poor Life to your virtue.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: What, Ladies? have you put um together for a brave Boy to night?

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: That's as the Dice run, Sir.

sp.speaker: La Gitt.
sp.p: The Collonel will find a piece of service on't to night

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: If he put her to the worst, 'twill be worth her pardon being so try'd a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Torguina.
sp.p: If his valour should be short-breath'd, a retreat may be honourable sometimes.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: If he fight not flat Coward, and made it in policy.

sp.speaker: Torguina.
sp.p: Sir, we have read over Aristotles Politiques and Polibius, to that purpose.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: Who calls Policy the very breath of all war.

sp.speaker: Torguina.
sp.p: And so by your Ladyships good license, in all Battalions, leaguers, skirmishes, sieges, invasions, parlies, treaties, truces, and other cessations.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Excellent Ladies.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: For the Theorique.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: We can say some thing to the practique too, Seignior.

sp.speaker: Torguina.
sp.p: Both concerning your postures and motions, as which may be necessary for service: her Ladyship has written a small tract for her private experience to shew how they may be reduced, and a Man exercis'd with far lesse trouble, but with as much Activity, and proportion of comfort.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: For body▪ and service, Madam?

sp.speaker: Torguina.
sp.p: I mean so: I warrant you this Gentleman understands me.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: And will not your goodnesse bestow it on the publique? It would rank your Name amongst the illustrious benefactors of the general Cause.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: I know not what I may Sir, when the Press is fit for a woman of my Quality: Is this Gentleman a Soldier?

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: That ambition has grown with me from the Cradle, Madam.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: I shall render my self with more endeerment to your worth, and ever subscribe to Soldiers as the bravest Men.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: The Dutchesse, I hope will use of your opinion; But Madam, had I the use of that key for an hour or two, I would take some notes in short-hand behind the hangings.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: You wou'd?

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Yes indeed, my precious wit, I shou'd.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: That Key?

sp.speaker: Torguina.
sp.p: Seignior? pleaseth you to think our humble invitation, worthy the grant of your society.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: I could wish the trouble of ten lives more, to be accepted in your Command, Fairest of Ladies,

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: Were all our dayes multiplied into years, and those years to lives, 'twere but a span of time to study our thanks in▪—

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: Madam? Lady?—
I never knew what Bondage was until now— I fear the Golden heart you sent me, was enchanted: I long to see you—

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: What d'ye mean Sir?

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha: hum—Nothing, Madam, but there be them that love a good nature with all their heart: that have Four hundred pounds a year, and money in their purse, to be Knighted, if need be.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: Wit and opportunity assist me— The Thing will make an excellent husband for the times: And Four hundred pounds a year is a Considerable fortune to boot: I must take him at his bound, or perhaps dye in the Lift of stale Chambermaids, A Court plague for a mispent youth and service.

sp.speaker: Silli.
sp.p: I am a Gentleman already, else the Heralds took my mony for nothing: And methinks Madam, you and I might—

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: What Signior?

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: Be as wise as our Forefathers.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: You and I?

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: Yes; what say ye to you and I? is not you and I good Spanish? Why Madam, I am able to warm my own sheets, and get Children without the help of a Doctor, and can kisse as warm and Close— And you shall swear my breath is sweet.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: Y'are merry Sir, beyond my apprehension

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: Pardon me Lady if I be: I mean no harm I protest.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: very witty.

sp.speaker: Silli.
sp.p: I am, what I am: but I was never beholding to any living thing for thus—much wit: I might a been an arrant younger brother, but for my mother; thereby hangs a tale Madam: And yet I cud a danc'd my Cinque pace in Greek at a dozen: Alpha, Beta, Gama, Delta, cost me five shillings: can you beleeve me Lady? By this Light you shall wear this Diamond: There; shat; shat ha't; shat, shat: shat ha't,

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: There is such sorcery in your words.

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: No: No: No: Troth love me: come; thou shalt; by this—nay never sigh, my dear, they are all orient, sweet wench: thou art worth all Spain for a good disposition—

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: You will undoe me Mr. Steward.

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: Pish: who I undo thee? My life, thou dost wrong me: canst find in thy heart to think so? away away.

sp.speaker: La Prate,
sp.p: But is this profession, honourable Sir?

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: I scorn to deal upon dishonorable terms: Do I kisse like a man that would Propound dishonorable conditions?

sp.speaker: La Prate
sp.p: Men are so nice and cunning.

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: Dost think me a Jew? swear me to any thing.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: Well, you have taken a Poor heart at advantage and make me blush to confesse it.

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: Kisse me; here's my hand till death us do part: Thine more then mine own, Signior Bouche overte, Sillimano: Seal'd, and delivered: but I hope Lady, there is no Quit rent to be paid out of this Copyhold.

sp.speaker: La Prate.
sp.p: Not for your life Sir.

sp.speaker: Silliman.
sp.p: Lawful possession then, and th'art mine own

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: So; let um drench their souls in Laughter: Kindle thy Noble heart into a Flame, my Sister: Fate cannot give, nor we ask more unto our cause: All things conspire and Prompt us to't: Just, and Divine revenge; I'le strew thy midnight haunts with Cypresse wreaths, and wear thee in rich Medalls: Propitious Goddesse: This night thy wan, and meager Cheek shall blush and smile with warm and wanton blood: Night grows heavy ey'd and droops her slumbering head in her dark bosome: And now their Rage and Lust, will make them ripe to bleed: Let us imbrace, and interchange a sigh or two, Cleara: what e're become of me, thou wilt wear Chaplets in Elizium.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: My hopes and Joys are yours (dear Sir)
And heaven I hope will not divide them.

sp.speaker: De Fl.
sp.p: See what a modest blush, sleep has cast o're their Guilt.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Here is a look Tyrants would bashfully gaze at and fear to think it mortal: Glorious hypocrisie! virtue is at wonder in her self, and looks pale, to own what she has given.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: I should mock heavens Justice, to let um dream their souls away in such a calm: Wee'l startle them into horror of their sin, and then let 'um see the vengeance they deserve.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
Claudilla.
sp.p: Oh:—Dessandro?—oh—whose hand's that?

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Cleara's, Cleara's, carry that name in thy last breath down to the shades of Lust and Perjury.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: So quick, and brave Cleara?

sp.speaker: Claudilla.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Dessan. Cleara:
sp.p: Madam, Madam, your sleeps are troubled— whose there, De Flame?

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Raise not thy voice an accent: If thou dost, by my eternal hopes and soul, this strikes it back unto thy heart: Seest thou revenge sit Pale upon the Point? 'Tis steel'd with Virgins curses, and shall flye like lightning through thy blood: And it is a Justice thy vast pride hath lost thee to.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Oh! what hast thou done? A deed that Flinty Scythians and curl'd Ethiops would hide their eyes from.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Our Revenge shall wear a Glorious title: Know'st thou that injur'd face? It is Cleara's, injur'd Cleara's.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Cleara?

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: What see'st thou on that brow?

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Murder!

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Horror and Guilt unto thy soul.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: I'le not be tamely butcher'd, Coward: without there? Help help help.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Whirlewinds and Earthquakes cannot do it; think on thy sin.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p: Thy Perjury.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Thy Lust.

sp.speaker: Dessandro.
sp.p: Cleara? Oh—thou hast a skilfull hand in Murder: Help, Help, Murder.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: So falls a wretched Statue from its haughty station: when Fate, would make it ominous and fright a state. What a thick cloud steems from his tainted blood: The Air shrinks back, and with dull wings fans it from heaven.

div.stage: Enter De Loome, La Gitterne, Torguina, &c.

sp.speaker: Torguina.
sp.p: Murder! Murder! 'Twas his voice.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: It was his voice.

sp.speaker: Torguina.
sp.p: The Key?

sp.speaker: La Gitterne.
sp.p: Gone!

sp.speaker: Torguina.
sp.p: Cut from my side; I am betray'd.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Look search the Room: where's the stranger?

sp.speaker: La Gitterne.
sp.p: The Dore is fast.

sp.speaker: De Fl.
sp.p: You may come in; make up your wonder there

sp.speaker: Torguina.
sp.p: My Lady Murder'd?

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: You have astonish'd Heaven,

sp.speaker: Torguina.
sp.p: And pull'd eternal curses on your head.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: They'l fall like brittle shafts upon my sheild.

sp.speaker: Cleara.
sp.p:
Unjust Dessandro! yet on thy Lip I'le tender my last
vows, that the world may tell, I lov'd thee Dead—and this— and this—

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: Hold; hold that cruel hand: Cleara? Sister?

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Cleara? This is a horrid Scene, my Lord.

sp.speaker: De Flame.
sp.p: 'Twould not be worth my Name, did it not strike Amazement through your souls, and leave a palenesse on his Cheek that hears it. But here; here I could melt! Transfuse my brains through my sad eyes, till they wept blood, & dropt their Jelly forth: She was a Jewel, too rich for our dull Orb: [Enter more servants you need not multiply your fears: I am too proud of my Revenge to start from't: Let the Law frown, and fall in Tempests on me:—Cowards repent
When valiant blood ne're Pales at the Event.

div.head: Actus Quintus; Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: De Loom.
sp.p: A Sad Court indeed, My Lord.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: As sad a Kingdom where the news is spread: men that hear it, stand struck, as if their own passing-bells did call unto them.

sp.speaker: De Loom.
Pirez.
sp.p: His death is much admit'd for the sudden strangeness of it: What opinion give the Physicians on't?

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: Th'ave a hard Name for't, if I could think on't.

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: Not suspicion of Poison?

sp.speaker: De Loome.
sp.p: How, my Lord? by whom wou'd ye suspect it?

sp.speaker: Pirez.
sp.p: Nay, I dare suspect none, nor don't: but such Quirks of State I have read of, in the dayes of old.

sp.speaker: De Loome.
